Fields.DialogueText: Hello there, Capitano.
Good to see you, Savoia. What are you reading today?
Moby Dick.

Fields.MenuText: Ah, yes. "Call me Ishmael."
I haven't read that one.
Seems appropriate.

Fields.DialogueText: If you insist, Ishmael!
It's quite a book, although I think I've learned more about whales than I ever wanted to.
I enjoyed reading Billy Budd, so I might as well tackle Herman Melville's more famous book.
You've been doing a lot of reading lately.
Well, things have been so quiet. We haven't seen a Morgana in... forever.
The crew needed the opportunity for rest. You know, it's almost enough to make me wonder if the war-
*ALARM*
Hmph. Right on cue. Shall we, then?
@BATTLE
Bracing for impact, Captain!
@BATTLE
I want damage control on deck.
Aye-aye, Captain.
Capitano, I've been thinking.
I don't doubt it.
You know how I've been getting a lot of reading in lately? Well, the Morganas remind me of one of the books I've read.
Is that so?
Sì. Dracula.

Fields.MenuText: Was that a joke, Savoia?
Let's just hope we don't get close enough to one to find out if they suck blood.
Hmm, maybe we should be using blessed ammo, then?

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you for noticing, Capitano. I thought it was quite droll.
Oh, I'm not afraid. I've got plenty of garlic.
Don't be silly, Capitano.
Capitano, do you see that? On the horizon?
Yes, it's a... plume of smoke!
I think we should go check it out.
I think you're right.
*ALARM*
At your stations!
@BATTLE
The Morganas are finally withdrawing, Captain.
Very good. Now let's investigate this smoke.
It... it was a fishing village. The Morganas...

Fields.MenuText: A battleship's guns can be turned on coastal targets with devastating effect.
This is bad, even for Morganas.
That's war, unfortunately.

Fields.DialogueText: And my guns were made for fighting Morganas.
Sì. It is.
But does it have to be?
Sailor, in what direction did that Morgana task force retreat?
Plotting it on the charts now, ma'am.
Have I ever told you about my namesake, Eugene of Savoy?
No, you haven't.
Denied a military career in France, he left to serve in Austria and became one of the Holy Roman Empire's greatest generals. In all things, discipline ruled his life.

Fields.MenuText: It seems like you really admire him.
Sounds boring.
As it rules yours.

Fields.DialogueText: I do, Capitano.
Oh, psssh.
I try to live up to my namesake.
Statesmen, general, supporter of the arts - he was a great leader!
*ALARM*
And a consummate fighter. I'm about to emulate him some more right now!
@BATTLE
I see more smoke on the horizon.
@BATTLE
Another coastal town.
Savoia?
Hm? Yes, Capitano?
Are you all right?
Sì, Capitano...

Fields.MenuText: This is really concerning.
How many villages are these Morganas going to hit?
Are you sure you're okay?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, it is.
Until we can stop her? Who knows?
I'll be fine.
Well, let's go, then.
Captain, we've sighted another raided coastal village. No sign of Morgana activity.
Damn! Nothing but cold ashes.
These Morgana beasts are slippery ones.
Even when we can catch up, they still manage to get away.
Capitano, how many coastal settlements are there in this region? Towns and villages, like this one, I mean.
Oh, I imagine there must be hundreds, nestled in here and there.
Hundreds of places for her to strike. How can we protect so much?

Fields.MenuText: What would Eugene have done?
We will do what we have always done. Our best.
Patrolling, I suppose.

Fields.DialogueText: He would have preferred the direct approach.
Of course. Thank you, Capitano.
I'm not quite sure that will be enough.
Morganas sighted!
Not the same group, but I suppose it will have to do.
@BATTLE
I will not rest until this Morgana raid force is destroyed.
@BATTLE
Capitano, I've been thinking.
Oh?
This Morgana force has been attacking fishing villages, right?
Yes, and leaving hardly anything behind to save.
Exactly.
Huh? What are you getting at?
Capitano, those were fishing villages, right? Well, how many fishing boats have you seen?
Hm...

Fields.MenuText: That's a good point. Where did they all go?
Perhaps they fled?
How important can they be? They're only fishing boats.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not totally sure yet, but I think I have an idea.
All of them? Every time? Without leaving any wreckage? I think it's something else, Capitano.
If I'm right, it could mean the war.
I'll keep an eye out for fishing boats from now on. We'll see if we can get to the bottom of this.
Another ruined village, Capitano.
Damn. Looks like we were too late to do anything.
Wait! Look!
Give me my binoculars, sailor. There! I see it!
A child.
Prepare the boat, Lieutenant.
¡Ayuadame! ¡Quiero a mi mami! ¡Quiero a mi papi!
Um, shh. It'll be okay.
Ah, pequeño. Estas a salvo ahora.
¡Ah, la dueña de la nave!

Fields.MenuText: Are you crying, Savoia?
I never thought of you as a hugger.
We saved someone, at least.

Fields.DialogueText: Am I?
There's a first time for everything.
It is a start, isn't it?
*ALARM*
Let's get out of here quickly. Lay down suppressing fire!
@BATTLE
Keep it up! As we do these drills, strive to improve your skills!
How are the gunnery drills coming?
Good, Capitano.
You've been at them a while.
The crew needs the practice. That Morgana encounter...
It's tough, yes. But you need to take a break. Come on. The officers and I are playing cards.
I'm sorry, but I can't right now.

Fields.MenuText: The crew doesn't need the practice, Savoia. You're just anxious.
Gunnery drills won't bring that village back.
Savoia, as your captain, I order you to come play cards with us.

Fields.DialogueText: I-- you're right, Capitano.
And I suppose exhaustion won't, either.
Very well, Capitano.
Now, how are you at bridge?
I've never played.
Excellent, then you can be Lt. Silvio's partner.
*ALARM*
Damn. Looks like that'll have to wait.
@BATTLE
I can't believe that worked.
You were right about playing cards, Capitano. I feel a lot better.
You weren't kidding about being bad, though.
Sorry about that.
"She's your ship," they said. "You be partners with her."
Look, I said I was sorry.

Fields.MenuText: Apologizing won't take away that crushing defeat.
I know, I'm just joking.
Lt. Silvio is never going to let this go.

Fields.DialogueText: Do you see what I'm doing right now? I'm rolling my eyes. Do you see?
Oh, is that so?
And neither will you, it appears.
I am glad you're feeling better, Savoia.
Morganas sighted!
Well, let's hope she doesn't want to play bridge.
@BATTLE
Una patata, dos patatas, tres patatas, cuatro...
Is he playing with ammunition?
Oh, don't worry, Capitano. It's not live ammo.
Um, okay. What are we going to do with him?
I'm not sure. A warship is certainly no place for a child.
I agree with you there.

Fields.MenuText: Does he have any family?
Is there any kind of foster family we can find for him?
Could he be a cabin boy?

Fields.DialogueText: It seems most of his family was in the village. And... he doesn't want to talk about that yet.
Maybe, but how will we get him there? I don't think we can spare the time to take him anywhere right now.
A cabin boy? In this day and age?! Perhaps Professor Marlborough did have an effect on you.
*ALARM*
Get him below decks, now.
@BATTLE
We've got activity on the radar, Captain!
It's the Morgana raiders!
At your stations, sailors! I'm not letting her get away this time!
Looks like we caught her red-handed! Helm, all engines ahead full!
"From hell's heart I stab at thee!"
@BATTLE
We gave them a pounding, but they've escaped. Again.
Damn. No matter how hard we hit them, they slither away...

Fields.MenuText: Swearing, Savoia?
I'm getting tired of this Morgana.
Damn.

Fields.DialogueText: I think I've earned one by now, Capitano.
Me, too.
Damn.
Any word from the villager's survivors?
Not really. Frightened, but accounted for. And the fishing boats were all present.
Strange.
Keep on her, sailor.
Yes ma'am!
What's going on?
Ah, Capitano, you're awake. We got a hit on the radar. It's them.

Fields.MenuText: Figures I'd almost sleep through it.
How can you be sure?
Did you say you've been reading Moby Dick?

Fields.DialogueText: You're awake now.
I just know.
What's that got to do with anything?
Bring all guns to bear.
We all will, Lieutenant.
@BATTLE
Aye-aye, Capitano. We'll do our best.
Well, we really hammered that Morgana group. I think we have them on the ropes now.
Morganas sighted!
Ah, that'll be our villain and her friends. Shall we finish this, then?
Wait. The lead Morgana... she's... she's... signaling us with her flags?!
You can come get me, but my sisters have found a poor, defenseless merchant vessel nearby. If you catch me, who will come to its rescue?

Fields.MenuText: It's a trick! Stay on course, helm.
Better rescue the civilians.
What do you think we should do, Savoia?

Fields.DialogueText: I just picked up a distress call on the radio, Capitano. She's not lying.
Do you think that's wise, Capitano?
... I don't know, Capitano.
Are we just going to let her get away?
Yes.
But...
Civilians are in danger, Savoia. We can't waste any time coming to their aid.
@BATTLE
Damn! Alter course.
We don't have time for this. Helm, all ahead full. We're heading for those civilians.
Savoia? What happened back there?
I'm sorry about that, Capitano. Protecting civilians should be my first priority, and I lost sight of that.
It was just so out of character for you.
I know that, and I'm sorry.

Fields.MenuText: Just as long as it doesn't happen again.
You don't need to apologize to me.
What's wrong?

Fields.DialogueText: It won't, Capitano.
Grazie, Capitano.
Nothing, Capitano.
What's come over you? It's as if all you care about is defeating this one Morgana.
She's targeting civilians. That's unacceptable.
*ALARM*
We'll talk about this more later.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Morgana sighted!
It's her! Capitano, give me your binoculars.
What are you looking for?
I was right! Capitano, look. What do you see?

Fields.MenuText: Avarice.
She looks... sturdier than the last time we saw her.
Her silhouette certainly doesn't look like any ship I recognize.

Fields.DialogueText: Sì, but look closer!
Exactly!
Sì! And I think I know why.
Avarice uses the fishing boats to repair herself.
Of course!
It's why she seems to recover from every fight so quickly, no matter how hard we hit her.
And it explains why she's going after the fishing villages - they're an easy supply of materials.
We have to stop her!
@BATTLE
Those look like Morgana hulls over the horizon. Sound the alarm.
The child should really stay below decks. We are going into battle.
@BATTLE
¡Bang!
Do you think it's healthy for such a young child to be exposed to so many guns?
What, are some of them pointing at him?
What? No. I just don't know if a kid his age should be so accustomed to violence.
His village was burned down by a malevolent, parasitic warship. I think that ship has sailed, so to speak.

Fields.MenuText: Okay, you got me.
Well, no need to get... snarky.
Good one.

Fields.DialogueText: That's what I'm here for.
Sorry, Capitano.
Grazie, Capitano.
¡Rat-a-tat-tat-tat!
Do we even have that caliber onboard?
Mind if I bring the kid up here for a bit, ma'am? He's tired of the engine room, I think.
I can send him to gunnery drills, if you'd like.
Capitano, I've plotted the locations of all the coastal attacks Avarice has made on this chart.
Oh?
Sì, and I think I figured something out. See what I mean?
She has a base.
Of some sort, at least. Not much there, though - just some rocks, really.

Fields.MenuText: Well, every ship needs a port.
Rocks could mean an anchorage.
How sure are you of this?

Fields.DialogueText: That's what they tell me.
My very thought.
Very, Capitano. At the least, she likes to spend her days off here.
It looks like we'll have to set sail for this... nest?
Very good. Although, a word of caution. We--
*ALARM*
Well, we've got something else to take care of first, anyway.
@BATTLE
¡Más alto! ¡Más alto! ¡Hahaha!
Where did he get a kite?
Oh, one of the mechanics made it up for him out of some old stuff he had.
He's kind of become our little mascot, hasn't he?
I suppose so.
Will he talk about anything, yet?
No. To be honest, I haven't even gotten his name. He'll seem to want to talk about anything except his past.

Fields.MenuText: Can't say I really blame him.
Keep trying. He has some valuable intelligence.
In that, he reminds me of a friend of mine.

Fields.DialogueText: Nor I, Capitano.
I will, although I will admit children are not my strong suit.
I don't know what you're talking about.
*ALARM*
Kite time is over, kid.
@BATTLE
I feel like screaming! She stays one step ahead of us!
@BATTLE
Why do you care so much about this particular Morgana? There are so many out there. Why this one?
It's my duty to protect civilians, Capitano. And she's targeting them.
That's what you said earlier, and it is true, but I don't think that's why you're so focused on her. There's more to this.
What aren't you telling me?
I suppose it's time... It was during the Spanish Civil War. I was sent to assist Franco's forces.
On February 13th, 1937 I was sent to shell the city of Barcelona. It happened before I... woke up. I know I didn't do it, not really, but I remember it. It was me...
Oh, Savoia.
It's my personal Guernica. Civilians...

Fields.MenuText: It's not your fault.
I'm here for you.
You don't have to carry this burden alone.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, but... Hm. Grazie, Capitano.
Grazie, Capitano.
Grazie, Capitano, but the burden of guilt is mine.
You're awake now, Savoia, and now you can make decisions for yourself.
Then we keep fighting. We'll win only if we don't give up, Savoia.
I hadn't thought about that in a long time, but when I saw those villages that Avarice burned down...
And I won't let my opportunity pass, Capitano.
@BATTLE
You look like you could use a drink.
I think I could.
Scotch?
Sure.
Good, because it's all I have.
I believe a toast is traditional?

Fields.MenuText: To absent friends.
To a new tomorrow.
To the best damn ship in the Neutrality Fleet.

Fields.DialogueText: To absent friends.
... To a new tomorrow.
And to the best damn capitano in the Neutrality Fleet.
Did I ever tell you about my trip to South America?
You mentioned the Caribbean, but never South America.
Ah. Well, we spent some time anchored there at the mouth of the Amazon. You know, it's the largest river in the world, by volume.
Impressive.
I think it was the most alive thing I've ever seen. Just miles and miles of brown water, thick with dirt and fish and life.
It sounds lovely.
One day I saw jaguar ambush a caiman sunbathing by the river. There was nothing the caiman could do...
Sounds horrible.
And yet, there was something beautiful about it, too. The caiman never gave up. It kept thrashing, right up until the end.
*cough* This stuff really is awful.
You don't drink much, do you?
Morganas sighted. Guns up, Savoia!
Damn! I lost her again!
Tell the crew to man their battle stations, Capitan. We are about to engage with Avarice.
@BATTLE
I don't know if we can keep doing this, Savoia.
Capitano?
Every time we fight them, they're stronger. We lose crew, we take damage, people die, and every sunken merchantman or fishing boat only feeds them.
Ah, I see. Yes, I remember when they showed up. This seems a far cry from that, doesn't it?

Fields.MenuText: How do you kill what can't die?
What do we do?
Yes, a far cry indeed.

Fields.DialogueText: I guess you find a way of defeating it other than killing. That, or wait strange eons.
We do our duty with honor.
And yet, perhaps things are not so dire as we perceive.
Duty is our armor, discipline our ammunition. With these we cannot fail.
I sure hope you're right.
Capitan! Capitan!
What? What's happening?
The civilians from the fishing villages - they're alive.
What?!
The boy from the village - his name's Javier, by the way - finally felt like speaking up. Avarice took them... somehow.

Fields.MenuText: Of course! Even a Morgana needs a crew.
Can a kid's story really be good intel?
I'm glad he finally decided to tell us.

Fields.DialogueText: How could we not have thought of it before?
I don't know, but it makes sense. Who knows every strange power the Morganas have?
Well, he's been traumatized.
Do you know what this means, Capitan?
I think so.
It means we have a chance.
And this group of Morganas off the beam doesn't. Let's give them a beating, Savoia.
@BATTLE
Crew, we'll have one chance at this, and it isn't going to be easy.
We're going to have to pull up close to Avarice, under fire, and board her.
Lt. Silvio, I want you to handpick a boarding team, which you and I will lead. Your boats will hang back from the fight until we've got the Morganas defeated.
Then move in to recover the villagers while they're disabled.

Fields.MenuText: Recover as many as you can before you have to withdraw.
Savoia will keep her gunfire away from your waiting zone.
The window is going to be small. You won't have much time.

Fields.DialogueText: I can respect that, Capitano.
Not a single shell will touch your boats, Lieutenant Silvio.
We'll be ready, Capitano.
Okay, H-hour is approaching. Try to get some rest until then, because it won't be long.
@BATTLE
That's the signal! He's got them, Savoia! Cover Lieutenant Silvio's exit.
They won't lay so much as a glance upon him, Capitano!
Our rescue team knows the risks. Each member is a volunteer, and we're dedicated to the task, Capitano.
Are all the refugees back home?
Nearly. The last boat is about to leave, then all will be accounted for.
We accomplished something here, Savoia.
We did, didn't we?
What are you reading now?
Oh, I'm finishing up Dracula. It's an interesting novel. Really, it's about... well... many things.
No, what?
Friendship. No, don't laugh. In the end, it was the alliance of six loyal friends that destroyed Dracula. Nothing else.

Fields.MenuText: I'll settle for a 120mm gun, personally.

Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
It seems our work never ends, Capitano.
But, really, would you want it to?
The last of the refugees are safe, Capitano, and our boats are stowed.
Very well. Full speed ahead, Lieutenant!
I would. Maybe it takes an alliance of six friends, or sixty thousand, but I want these vampires destroyed.

Fields.MenuText: Not a subtle lesson, is it?
It's dangerous to go alone.

Fields.DialogueText: We still need reminding sometimes, Capitano.
Six loyal friends with naval guns might have conquered Dracula sooner, I suppose!
I won't let you go alone, Capitano.
